trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of altering local anaesthetic concentration on nerve block duration for arthroscopic shoulder surgery
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of altering ropivacaine concentration on interscalene block duration for arthroscopic shoulder surgery

interventions.interventions:
Patients undergoing elective arthroscopic shoulder surgery will receive an ultrasound guided interscalene nerve block with 20mls of a randomly allocated ropivacaine concentration.
Arm 1 0.1% ropivacaine
Arm 2 0.2% ropivacaine
Arm 3 0.375% ropivacaine
Arm 4 0.75% ropivacaine
interventions.comparator: Active control - interscalene nerve block with 20mls of 0.75% ropivacaine

primaryOutcome.outcome: Duration before analgesic effect of block wears off as reported by the patient
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Checked at day 1 and day 2 post-operatively.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Shoulder pain as assessed using numeric verbal rating score at rest and on movement
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 15 minutes, 60 minutes, and 24 hours following surgery

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Motor block assessed by hand grip dynamometer
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre-op, in post anaesthetic care unit and the next day

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Respiratory function assessed by peak expiratory flow rate measured by a peak flow meter, and episodes of O2 saturation < 93% measured by a pulse oximeter
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre-op, in post anaesthetic care unit and the next day

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hoarse voice assessed clinically by anaesthetic nurse/doctor
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre-op, in post anaesthetic care unit and the next day

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Horners syndrome assessed clinically by anaesthetic nurse/doctor
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre-op, in post anaesthetic care unit and the next day

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Participant satisfaction with their analgesic care, scored with a verbal numeric scale 0-10.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Elective arthroscopic shoulder surgery Age 18-80 years ASA 1-3
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
Patient refusal
Previous involvement in this study
Contraindication to interscalene block (patient refusal, coagulopathy, sepsis, local infection, severe respiratory disease, allergy to ropivacaine)
Upper limb neurological disease or deficits
Opioid tolerance (defined as use of >30mg oral morphine/day or equivalent fentanyl patch 12mcg/hr, buprenorphine 20mcg/hr, oxycodone >20mg/day)
Contraindication to COX2 inhibitors/NSAIDs (renal impairment, NSAIDs/aspirin trigger asthma, active peptic ulcer disease, or allergy).

trial_design.concealment: Numbered syringes that were prepared with the randomly allocated ropivacaine concentration
trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomisation using online computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Arthroscopic shoulder surgery may produce severe pain that is a challenge to control. Interscalene nerve blocks have been shown to be an excellent method of analgesia. It is not clear what concentration of local anaesthetic should be used for interscalene blocks to maximise pain relief and minimise side-effects. We aim to determine if lower compared to higher concentrations of ropivacaine (a local anaesthetic) can produce comparable pain relief duration with less side-effects.
